events.name: Introduction to Cloud Firestore with Google Developer Expert Juan Herrera
events.description:
Join us for an evening with GDE Juan Herrera who leading a talk and a hands-on workshop on how to use Cloud Firestore with your web applications.

Firestore is new real-time sync NoSQL database from Google Cloud. Learn more about Firestore here: https://firebase.google.com/docs/firestore/

Title: Firestore and Angular: Prototyping your app in no time
Description: Implement your next business idea in record time with Firestore, the new Firebase real-time database that combines the best of performance and good practices

In this talk, we will build a real-time chat through live coding with Angular, AngularFire and Firestore. Step by step I'll demonstrate how the gap between the data layer and application is closed, boosting our productivity like never before.

Among the topics we are going to touch base on are:
Observables
Asynchronous Pipes
Offline capabilities
Non-SQL databases

After Juan's talk, we will have a hands-on workshop which will integrate Firestore into a VanillaJS web application. If you have javascript experience, you would be able to follow along.

6pm - Doors open, networking, beverages & food (pizza & non-dairy gluten free salad)
6:30pm - Talk starts
7:15pm - Hands-on Firestore workshop starts
8:45pm - Raffle, Clean-up, goodbyes!

Speaker Bio:
Juan Herrera (@jdjuan) is a Google Developer Expert in Angular. He is the Head of Front-End Development at Yuxi Global ðŸ’¾ where he provides consultancy in Angular to different companies. Organizer of Angular Medellin and NgColombia (The first Angular Conference in Latin America). Juan loves ðŸ’™ creating social web apps. In his spare time, he enjoys dancing ðŸ•º and singing ðŸŽ¤

Special thanks to our location sponsor the CIC Cambridge & food/beverage sponsor Google.

events.name: Women Techmakers Fall 2018 Kick Off
events.description:
Come join us at Google Cambridge for the Women Techmakers fall kick off!

We're marking the event with some light food and beverages, networking time, an introductory talk, and a panel of women in tech that will be there to share their experiences. We look forward to seeing you there!

Google's Women Techmakers program provides visibility, community, and resources for women in technology. If you'd like to learn more about WTM, feel free to visit https://www.womentechmakers.com. If you're not already a member, be sure to sign up on the membership page!

This event is for people who identify as women or non-binary only. If you have questions about this, please contact the organizers directly.

Registration opens at 6:00pm and please review the agenda below:

6:00pm - 7:00pm
- Dinner, Drinks, and Networking

- Professional headshots from event photographer available on a first come first serve basis

7:00pm - 8:00pm

- Welcome remarks from WomenTechMaker Leads & GDG Organizers Jessica Janiuk & Amal Hussein

- "Higher Standards" - A featured presentation on Open Web Standards, and open source governance from Jory Burson.

- A Short highlight of Girl Develop It Boston - Sara Cashman

- A Short highlight of Women Who Code Boston - Shayna Cummings

8:00pm - 9:15pm

- Panel Discussion:

Shayna Cummings, Software Engineer, Pluralsight

Sharon Diorio, UI Tech Lead, Achievement Network

Jessica Janiuk, Senior Software Engineer & Tech Lead, Spoiler Alert

Lauren Stephens, Senior Software Engineer, Google

Laura Stone, Senior Site Reliability Engineer, Klaviyo

Amal Hussein, Senior Open Web Engineer, Bocoup (moderator)

- Raffle of Awesome Things (Raspberry-Pi Kits, Google Home's, and more)
- Closing Remarks
events.how_to_find_us: If you're taking the T, head to the Kendall Square stop on the Red Line and walk East on Main st. The Google offices are on your right.

events.name: Hacktoberfest: Make Your First Open Source Contribution [GDI | WWCode | WTM]

venue.name: CIC Boston - 5th floor, Meridian Conference Room

events.description:
In celebration of Hacktoberfest, join Girl Develop It, Women Who Code, and Cambridge Women Techmakers and Google Developer Group in celebrating the awesome world of open source software!

Hacktoberfest is an annual celebration of the open source community. More details here: https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/

We'll provide support from setup to Git workflow, including a curated list of good first-time contributor issues and mentorship support for helping you get un-stuck during the event!

This event is open to all genders and skill levels. We encourage new developers to join us!

** IMPORTANT: Since this event is a collaboration between multiple groups, we won't be opening the RSVPs on this event - please RSVP via Girl Develop It Boston! https://www.meetup.com/Girl-Develop-It-Boston/events/255185755/ **

A big thanks to our hosts at CIC Boston and our sponsor, Bocoup!

Tentative Schedule:

10:00 - 10:30: Arrival, Registration
10:00 - 10:30: Optional Machine Clinic
10:30: Opening Remarks, Keynote
10:45 - 11:30: Optional Git/Github Workshop
11:30 - 3:30: Hack!
12:00: Lunch Provided
3:45: Wrap Up

Bring your laptop and come hack with us in a relaxed, supportive atmosphere! While this is not a class and there won't be any formal instruction, we'll give you lots of resources to get you started on your open source journey. Start contributing to open source and make some new friends!

Do you already contribute to open source? Consider volunteering to mentor first-time contributors! https://tinyurl.com/y9fsrwjp

Parking:
You can park at the 33 Arch Street garage for $11 from 5a-5p on Saturdays. Note: the entrance to this garage is on Hawley Street.

The CIC Boston is also easily accessible by all lines of the MBTA (Downtown Crossing, State St, Park St., and Government Center).

events.name: [Talks] Building Serverless Apps | Google Cloud for AWS Developers
events.description:
Join us for a fun Monday evening of introductory level talks on Google Cloud technologies! If you are web or mobile developer who is excited to get started with building serverless apps, or you are a curious to learn about the differences between Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and Amazon Web Services (AWS), we've got some seasoned speakers diving into those topics.

Schedule

6:00PM - 6:45PM - Dinner (not pizza) & Networking
6:45PM - 7:00PM - Welcome remarks & Announcements
7:00PM - 7:45 PM - Building Serverless Apps on Google Cloud - Joe Lust
7:45PM - 8:00PM - Q&A | Break | More Food
8:00PM - 8:30PM - Google Cloud for AWS Developers - Jeff Whelpley
8:30PM - 8:45PM - Q&A | Closing Remarks | Clean-up

Building Serverless Apps on Google Cloud - Joe Lust

With the advent of serverless, you don't need backend server skills to deliver bonafide web applications. Best of all, pay only for what you use, running for pennies and scaling to zero. At this session, we'll cover how to build event-driven, low latency web applications using just a few Python or Javascript blocks, with Google Cloud Functions and Firebase.

Joe Lust is a software factotum and engineer reinventing software testing at Mabl, using technologies from custom browser extensions to Kubernetes model training grids. Previously a lead developer of the MC10 medical IoT cloud, he has co-founded MDDetails and RunPartner, and organizes the GDG Boston Google Cloud meetup.

Google Cloud for AWS Developers - Jeff Whelpley

Description: For most of the past 6 years, GetHuman has used Amazon Web Services (AWS) for all hosting and other infrastructure needs. During the past year, however, GetHuman has started to shift more and more development onto Google Cloud Platform (GCP) instead. In this talk, Jeff will explain GCP from the point of view of someone who is intimately familiar with AWS. He will go over the motivations for why you may want to use GCP, give some tips on how to get the most out of GCP and provide a step-by-step approach to migrating from AWS to GCP.

Jeff Whelpley is the CTO at GetHuman. He is also a Google Developer Expert, co-organizer Boston Angular meetup, co-organizer Boston AI meetup

A big thanks to our food & venue sponsors Google Cloud & Brightcove, and speakers for their time and efforts.

Looking forward to seeing you all there!

events.name: [Day 1 Instructional Workshop] Building Actions for Google Assistant
events.description:
Join us for a 1.5-day dive into building Actions for Google Assistant - leading by Google Developer Expert, Allen Firstenberg.

On Friday evening, we will start with a hands-on instructional workshop covering how to:
- Get started with building your own custom Actions
- Supercharge your Actions with cloud-based machine learning tools
- Deploy your Actions and make them available to billions of devices

On Saturday, we will have a full-day hackathon where you can work on building your custom Actions with some help from us if you need it. We will then have a showcase at the end of the day. There will be prizes given to the top 5 Actions and some cool raffles items for everyone else.

You are welcome to attend only one event, but we would love to see you are both!

Agenda:
6:00pm - 6:30pm - Dinner (not pizza) & Networking
6:30pm - 6:35pm - Welcome Remarks (Jessica & Amal)
6:35pm - 6:40pm - Welcome Remarks from General Assembly (Jonathan)
6:40pm - 7:25pm - Google Assistant Lecture (Allen)
7:25pm - 8:40pm - Hands on Workshop
8:40pm - 9:00pm - Pitches & Team formation for Saturday Hackathon

The following tools must be in your environment for the workshop & hackathon:

- An IDE/text editor of your choice, such as WebStorm, Atom or Sublime.
- A terminal to run shell commands with NodeJS (v6+), npm, and git installed.
- Any modern web browser, such as Chrome, FireFox, Edge, Safari or Brave.
- An account on GitHub.com. (You can create one for free.)

Familiarity with JavaScript (ES6) is strongly recommended, although not required, to understand the webhook code used in the workshop.

More on the instructor:
Allen Firstenberg
Google Developer Expert for IoT, Google Assistant, Wearables, Identity
https://developers.google.com/experts/people/allen-firstenberg

Agenda:

Lunch Served 12pm

The following tools must be in your environment for the workshop & hackathon:

- An account on GitHub.com. (You can create one for free.)

Familiarity with JavaScript (ES6) is strongly recommended, although not required, to understand the webhook code used in the workshop.

More on the instructor:
Allen Firstenberg
Google Developer Expert for IoT, Google Assistant, Wearables, Identity

events.name: [Talks & Workshop] Flutter Live 2018
events.description:
Flutter is a new mobile UI framework from Google that allows developers to build multi-platform native apps (for Android and iOS) from a single codebase (Dart). It's expressive, performant - and open-source. (https://flutter.io/)

Flutter is used by Google and developers and organizations around the world to deliver beautiful native apps. Flutter is still in beta, however, large enterprises such as Alibaba, and Tencent have already hopped on the Flutter bandwagon.

On December 4th, the Flutter team will be hosting Flutter Live - a day of talks and updates on Flutter. (https://developers.google.com/events/flutter-live)

Join us for a streaming of the Flutter Live keynote followed by an introductory hands-on Flutter workshop. In this workshop, we will aim to get you setup and writing your very first Flutter app. Regardless of whether you have a web background, or are an experienced mobile developer, all are welcome to this workshop. Flutter uses Dart - a productive language which is very quick to pick up (https://www.dartlang.org/).

Agenda:

6:00pm - 6:30pm - Dinner (not pizza) & networking
6:30pm - 7:45pm - Flutter Live Keynote & Talks
7:45pm - 9:00pm - Introductory hands-on Flutter Workshop

What you will need for the introductory hands-on Flutter workshop:

- Flutter SDK (Setup in advance or day of https://flutter.io/docs/get-started/install)
- A physical device (Android or iOS) connected to your computer and set to developer mode and/or Emulator
- IDE editor (VSCode https://code.visualstudio.com/ is recommended but you can use your preferred editor. Android Studio or XCode are also fine)

Optional Emulator setup:

- The iOS simulator. (Requires installing XCode tools.)
- The Android emulator. (Requires setup in Android Studio.)

Many thanks to all our sponsors for this event:
- The Flutter team @ Google for food and swag
- Vivint Smart Home for our beautiful venue (https://www.vivint.com)
events.how_to_find_us: The Courthouse silver line stop is the closest T stop. The location is across from the Seaport Christmas Tree.

events.name: 2018 Holiday Party with special guest Myles Borins
events.description:
Join us for our end of year holiday party where we will have delicious food, desserts, drinks, music, swag, and a talk on Adventures in Ethical Computing from special guest Myles Borins. Myles is the Director of the NodeJS Techincal Steering Committee and a Developer Advocate at Google Cloud.

We'll also be inviting some local startups to demo and showcase their work throughout the evening, and will also be raffling off some fun hardware prizes.

Agenda:
6:00pm - 7:30pm - Dinner, drinks, networking, startup demos, raffles
7:30pm - 7:35pm - Welcome remarks & 2018 reflections
7:35pm - 8:05pm - Adventures in Ethical Computing - Myles Borins
8:05pm - 8:30pm - On Stage interview with Myles | Audience Q&A
8:30pm - 9:30pm - Dessert, drinks, more demos & raffles

Adventures in Ethical Computing

Machine learning algorithms can infer gender when translating from gender neutral languages to English due to bias in training data.
Hardware designed to control airbag release have resulted in the deaths of Short-stature drivers and children passengers due to bias.
An engineer from Volkswagen was recently sentenced to a 40 month prison term for their part in producing software that cheated at emissions tests for diesel automobiles.

You are responsible for the software and hardware you help to create. Ethically responsible, and potentially legally responsible. Through an examination of academic literature and case studies this talk will discuss the types of bias that can enter into the systems that we manufacture, and suggest ways that we can avoid bias to create better user experiences (and avoid jail time).

Guest Speaker Bio
Myles Borins is a developer, musician, artist, and maker. He works for Google as a developer advocate serving the Node.js ecosystem. He graduated with a Master of Music Science and Technology from c.c.r.m.a. Myles cares about the open web and healthy communities.

Many thanks to our event sponsors Google for food & swag, and Kayak for use of their venue space.

events.name: [WebRTC Talks] Low-latency Media & Real Time Communications for the Masses
events.description:
WebRTC has continued its crazy adoption with improved support in browser and native mobile platforms and a growing number of use cases ranging from smart doorbells to traditional call centers. We are gathering again at Google in Cambridge to discuss the latest updates on this technology, examine use cases, hear insights from local developers, and network with fellow practitioners.

TALKS
=============================================
* CHECKING IN ON WEBRTC - Chad Hart of cwh.consulting / webrtcHacks will give a brief industry update
* WEBRTC-BASED LIVE-STREAMING IN YOUTUBE - Ying Yin of YouTube will talk about how they implemented WebRTC for this popular real time broadcasting feature
* WEBRTC BEST PRACTICES FROM DEVELOPERS AND ENTERPRISES - Robert Welbourn of Twilio will share some of their recommendations for different environments
* ENSURING A QUALITY WEBRTC EXPERIENCE - Alexandrea Mellen and Carl Blume of Callstats.io will talk about common WebRTC implementation mistakes and how to avoid them
* LEVERAGING WEBRTC FOR COLLABORATION AND DRONES - Osama Alshaykh of NxTEC and Boston University Professor will discuss his architecture and learnings from his various WebRTC projects

SCHEDULE
=============================================
6:00 - 7:00 Reception
7:00 - 7:45 Talks
7:45 - 8:00 Refreshment break
8:00 - 8:45 Talks

If you are not familiar, WebRTC is an Internet standard, open source community, and developer movement bringing real time communications to the web, mobile apps, and connected devices with just a few web APIâ€™s.

Sponsored by YouTube, Google, Kranky Geek, and Callstats.io.

Co-hosted with the Google Developer Group (GDG) Cambridge and New England Software Engineers (NESE).

=============================================

Entrance into the Google building requires that your register with your full name. If you don't register with your full name building security will not let you enter the building. If you are registered on Meetup with just part of your name or an alias please provide your full name via the questionnaire or by messaging the organizers directly.

events.name: Learn how Technical Whiteboarding Practice was built for Google Assistant
events.description:
Join us for a talk and workshop led by Jessica Earley-Cha, a member of a Google Assistant team. Jessica will be walking through the end-to-end development and deployment workflow for building Techincal Whiteboarding Practice, an application on Google Assistant that allows developers to practice the scenario of technical interview.

The talk will be followed by a guided hands-on a workshop for beginners, and for folks who have attended our previous Assistant events or already have some experience working on the Assistant platform, we invite you to hack on your personal Action(s) and leverage Jessica's expertise if you would like feedback or need help with something.

Learn more about the Action we'll be walking through @ https://assistant.google.com/services/a/uid/0000007e018b269f

Agenda:
6:00PM - Dinner (not pizza) & Networking

6:30PM - Welcome Remarks & Announcements - Jessica Janiuk & Amal Hussein

6:35PM - Learn how Technical Whiteboarding Practice was built for Google Assistant - Jessica Earley-Cha, Developer Advocate for Google Assistant

7:30PM - Beginner Track: Guided Hands-on Workshop | Advanced Track: Hack Your Personal Action

9:00PM - Clean-up and wrap-up!

Thanks as always to our sponsors. Google for food, drinks, and expertise, and Kayak for the use of their beautiful venue.

events.name: 2019 TensorFlow Dev Summit Viewing Party
events.description:
Join us to learn about what's new for TensorFlow, the open source machine learning framework created by Google Brain. TensorFlow has democratized access to world-class machine learning tools. Learn more @ https://www.tensorflow.org.

On March 6th and 7th, the 2019 TensorFlow Dev Summit will be taking place in Sunnyvale, CA (https://www.tensorflow.org/dev-summit). In addition to watching the keynote and overview of TensorFlow 2.0, we'll be recapping key announcements from the entire Summit, and hosting a panel discussion.

Agenda

6:00pm - 6:30pm Dinner (not pizza) & Networking

6:30pm - 6:35pm Welcome Remarks

6:35pm - 7:30pm Watch Keynote + Overview of TensorFlow 2.0

7:30pm - 7:45pm Recap of Announcements & Talks at the Summit

7:45pm - 8:00pm Break

8:00pm - 8:45pm - Machine Learning Experts Panel & Audience Q&A

Thanks to Google for helping sponsor this event. We're excited to be co-hosting this event with GDG Boston Android and GDG Cloud Boston.

events.name: [ML Talks] Intro to Cloud AutoML & Creating Custom Models
events.description:
Join us for an evening of machine learning talks from Sara Robinson, and Yufeng Guo, Google Cloud Developer Advocate's with a focus and expertise in Machine Learning.

Our talks for the evening will be on getting starting with automated machine learning via Cloud AutoML, and then what the next steps are for using that as a springboard for how you can build your own custom models. All levels are welcome!

Agenda:
6:00PM - Dinner (not pizza) & Networking

6:30PM - Welcome Remarks & Announcements

6:35PM - Introduction to Cloud AutoML

7:15PM - The Path from Cloud AutoML to Custom Model

What comes after AutoML? You've created some models in Cloud AutoML, and they've been useful. But you want to see if there's some room for more improvement and customization. Let's see how to start building custom models and deploy them in production. You'll learn how to take advantage of state-of-the-art models, all while advancing your understanding of your data pipelines and machine learning.

8:45PM - Clean-up and wrap-up!

Thanks as always to our sponsors. Google Cloud for food, drinks, and expertise, and Google Cambridge for the use of their beautiful venue.

Directions & Parking:

Googleâ€™s office is right near the Kendall Sq. stop on the Redline.

If you are driving in, there is paid parking in the building and many paid parking garages in the immediate area. The most affordable paid parking can be found at http://www.greaterbostonparking.com/kendall.html

There is no parking validation. On-street metered parking is generally free after 8PM - most meters take credit cards but not all do. Parking in some of the MIT Lots after 5:00PM and weekends is free. More details about MIT parking can be found here: http://web.mit.edu/mitdlbc/www/parking.htm

events.name: Women Techmakers IWD Celebration: Women in Technical Leadership
events.description:
Join us at Wayfair for our Women Techmakers International Women's Day celebration on April 29th! Our theme for the event is on Women in Technical Leadership and we have an incredible line-up of speakers and panelists.

Google's Women Techmakers program provides visibility, community, and resources for women in technology. If you'd like to learn more about WTM, feel free to visit https://www.womentechmakers.com. If you're not already a member, be sure to sign up on the membership page.

Women Techmakers IWD celebrations have been taking place all over the world from March 1st - April 30th. Checkout more @ https://www.womentechmakers.com/iwd19

Agenda:

6:00pm - 6:30pm Registration, SWAG pick-up, Dinner, Drinks, Professional Headshots, Networking

6:30pm - 6:40pm Welcome Remarks Jessica Janiuk & Amal Hussein, Women Techmakers Ambassadors & GDG Organizers

6:45pm - 6:50pm Introducing our Featured WIT Community Group: Halyee Ham, Founder and Organizer of Women in Machine Learning and Data Science, WiMLDS Boston

6:50pm - 7:10pm Featured Talk from Jillian Kando, Engineering Manager, ezCater

7:10pm - 8:20pm Panel featuring engineering leadership from Facebook, Google and Microsoft

Fangfei Zhou - Software Engineer & Tech Lead, Facebook
Sara Spaulding - Principal Engineering Manager, Microsoft
Maria Guirguis - Software Engineering Lead, Microsoft
Tali Sason - Engineering Leader, Google

8:20pm - 9:00pm Raffles, Dessert, Professional Headshots, & Networking

This event is for people who identify as women or non-binary. If you have questions about this, please contact the organizers directly.

Thank you to our Google and Wayfair for their generous sponsorship which allowed us to make this event happen!

Directions & Parking:
Wayfair is located inside the offices at Copley Place - so you will have to walk through the shopping area to get upstairs. Detailed directions can be found @ http://bit.ly/wayfair-directions

For those driving, some low-cost parking options:
Clarendon Street Garage â€“ $10 after 5pm
Back Bay Garage - $10 after 5pm
